Beta-lactamase found in Escherichia coli clinical isolates in Nepal.
NDM-14 is a beta-lactamase found in Acinetobacter lwoffii.
From the Lahey list of beta-lactamases.
Assigned by Lahey's list of beta-lactamases, not yet released
Present in Lahey's list of beta-lactamases, not yet released
QnrB75 is a fluoroquinolone resistance gene in Lahey's list of qnr genes
QnrB76 is a fluoroquinolone resistance gene in Lahey's list of qnr genes
QnrB77 is a fluoroquinolone resistance gene in Lahey's list of qnr genes
QnrB78 is a fluoroquinolone resistance gene in Lahey's list of qnr genes
QnrB79 is a fluoroquinolone resistance gene in Lahey's list of qnr genes
QnrB80 is a fluoroquinolone resistance gene in Lahey's list of qnr genes
QnrVC7 is a fluoroquinolone resistance gene in Lahey's list of qnr genes.
GIM-2 is a metallo-beta-lactamase present on an integron found in clinical isolates of Enterobacter cloacae in Germany

The GIM beta-lactamases are isolated from Pseudomonas aeruginosa. They are located in a distinct integron structure. They confers high broad spectrum resistant, including all C-lactams, aminoglycosides and quinolones.
tet45 is a tetracycline efflux pump found in Bhargavaea cecembensis strain previously isolated from a poultry-litter-impacted soil.
streptomycin/spectinomycin resistance gene found in Pasteurella multocida isolated from bovine respiratory tract

rmtH is a 16s ribosomal RNA methyltransferase found in Klebsiella pneumoniae strain MRSN2404 that was isolated from the chronic wound of a soldier wounded in Iraq in 2006. It confers high resistance to all aminoglycosides
AAC(6')-Iak is a 6'-N-aminoglycoside acetyltransferase-encoding gene isolated from a multidrug-resistant clinical isolate of Stenotrophomonas maltophilia

AAC(6')-Ian is an amikacin acetyltransferase gene found on a transferable plasmid of the Serratia marcescens strain NUBL-11663. IT catalyze the transfer of an acetyl group from acetyl coenzyme A onto an amine at the 6'-position of various aminoglycosides.
The TLA beta-lactamases are resistant to expanded-spectrum cephalosporins, aztreonam, ciprofloxacin, and ofloxacin but was susceptible to amikacin, cefotetan, and imipenem.

TLA-1 is a beta-lactamase found in plasmids of clinical isolates of Escherichia coli strain R170 in Latin America. It preferentially hydrolyzed cephaloridine, cefotaxime, cephalothin, benzylpenicillin, and ceftazidime. The enzyme was markedly inhibited by sulbactam, tazobactam, and clavulanic acid.
TLA-2 is a beta-lactamase is present on a plasmid isolated from an unidentified bacterial strain from a waste water treatment plant. The enzyme mostly hydrolyzes cephalosporins.
TLA-3 is a beta-lactamase found in a transferable plasmid of Serratia marcescens clinical isolate. It confers resistance to ceftazidime, cefotaxime and cefepime, but not to cefmetazole and meropenem
Erm(43) is a macrolide, lincosamide, and streptogramin B resistance gene found in Staphylococcus lentus chromosome isolated from human, dog and chicken.
lsaE is a ABC transporter gene found in porcine MRSA isolates. It confers resistance to pleuromutilin, lincosamide, and streptogramin A
FosK is a fosfomycin thiol transferase isolated from Acinetobacter soli. It is integrin-mediated. It confers a high level of resistance to fosfomycin.
fosXCC is a fosfomycin resistance gene that modifies MurA isolated from Campylobacter species. It is highly resistant to fosfomycin.

fosA5 is a fosfomycin resistance gene isolated from clinical strain of Escherichia coli E265. It is susceptible to amikacin, tetracycline and imipenem, and resistant to sulphonamide, cephalosporins, gentamicin, ciprofloxacin, chloramphenicol and streptomycin
fosA4 is an enzyme that confers resistance to fosfomycin in Escherichia coli by breaking the epoxide ring of the molecule.

term.name: 16S rRNA with mutation conferring antibiotic resistance

def.defstr: Many antibiotics inhibit the growth of bacteria by blocking protein synthesis on the ribosome. The antibiotic-binding sites are located within functionally important structures in the ribosomal RNA. Antibiotic resistance is often conferred by base substitutions or methylations at these sites in the rRNA. Point mutations in the bacterial 16S ribosomal RNA in the small 30S subunit can confer resistance to antibiotics.

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to edeine

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' minor domain of the 16S rRNA in Escherichia coli can confer resistance to edeine

Precursor molecule during the synthesis of bacterial cell wall. Lipid II anchors itself onto the cell and it's disaccharide-peptide subunit is used in PG polymer assembly by peptidoglycan glycosyltransferases. Due to it's importance in cell wall synthesis, it is the target of antibiotics.

Lipid III is the precursor to the wall teichoic acid. It's inhibition leads to bacterial death as teichoic acid is required to anchor autolysins which control the hydrolysis of peptidoglycan cell wall.

term.name: Mycobacterium abscessus 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to kanamycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium abscessus conferring resistance to kanamycin

term.name: Mycobacterium abscessus 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to tobramycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium abscessus conferring resistance to tobramycin

term.name: Mycobacterium abscessus 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to neomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium abscessus conferring resistance to neomycin

term.name: Mycobacterium abscessus 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to amikacin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium abscessus conferring resistance to amikacin

term.name: Mycobacterium abscessus 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to gentamicin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium abscessus conferring resistance to gentamicin

Teixobactin is a peptide antibiotic isolated from the Gram-negative bacteria, Eleftheria terrae. It inhibits the synthesis of peptidoglycan by interacting with peptidoglycan precursor, Lipid II and Lipid III.
bcrC is an undecaprenyl pyrophosphate phosphatase that has a role in bacitracin resistance if it is overexpressed. It is isolated from Bacillus subtilis.
Undecaprenyl pyrophosphate is a precursor to a cell wall polymer carrier. It's activation requires a phosphatase.
Genes that provide a bacteria with resistance to bacitracin
Subunit of topoisomerase IV sensitive to aminocourmarins

term.name: antibiotic sensitive DNA topoisomerase subunit gyrA

def.defstr: DNA gyrase is responsible for DNA supercoiling and consists of two alpha and two beta subunits. Binding the alpha-subunit is sufficient to inhibit DNA supercoiling.

term.name: antibiotic sensitive DNA topoisomerase subunit parC

def.defstr: ParC is a subunit of topoisomerase IV, which decatenates and relaxes DNA to allow access to genes for transcription or translation. Targeting topoisomerase IV inhibits DNA synthesis, and may also lead to double-stranded cell breaks.

term.name: antibiotic sensitive DNA topoisomerase subunit parY

def.defstr: parY is a subunit of the topoisomerase IV. It decatenates and relaxes DNA to allow for transcription or translation.

term.name: antibiotic sensitive DNA topoisomerase subunit parE

def.defstr: ParE is a subunit of topoisomerase IV, which decatenates and relaxes DNA to allow access to genes for transcription or translation. Targeting topoisomerase IV inhibits DNA synthesis, and may also lead to double-stranded cell breaks.
Beta-subunit of DNA gyrase sensitive to inhibition by aminocoumarins
Beta-subunit of DNA gyrase sensitive to inhibition by fluoroquinolones
Sensitive form of 16s susceptable to antibiotics
Sensitive form of 16s susceptable to antibiotics
Sensitive form of 16s susceptable to antibiotics

term.name: Amikacin sensitive Mycobacterium abscessus 16S rRNA mutation

def.defstr: Sensitive form of 16s susceptable to antibiotics

Cardiolipin synthetase catalyzes the formation of cardiolipin from two phosphatidylglycerol molecules. Cardiolipin is important in membrane translocation and permeabilization. Mutations on the enzyme confers resistance to antibiotics.

term.name: cell membrane component enzymes targeted by antibiotic

def.defstr: Interaction with the cell membrane phospholipids interferes with membrane permeability and integrity, leading to the leakage of cell contents. The outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria is particularly sensitive.

Cardiolipin synthetase catalyzes the formation of cardiolipin from two phosphatidylglycerol molecules. Cardiolipin is important in membrane translocation and permeabilization. The inactivation of this enzyme by antibiotics leads to cell death.

Cardiolipin synthetase catalyzes the formation of cardiolipin from two phosphatidylglycerol molecules. Cardiolipin is important in membrane translocation and permeabilization. Mutations on the enzyme confers resistance to Daptomycin

RNA polymerase is a multisubunit enzyme that is necessary for transcription. The beta-subunit of RNA polymerase forms the active center of the enzyme and template/transcript binding sites. Mutations in rpoB gene confers antibiotic resistance

term.name: antibiotic sensitive beta-subunit of RNA polymerase (rpoB)

def.defstr: RNA polymerase is a multisubunit enzyme that is necessary for transcription. The beta-subunit of RNA polymerase forms the active center of the enzyme and template/transcript binding sites. This enzyme can be inactivated by antibiotics leading to cell death.

term.name: daptomycin sensitive beta-subunit of RNA polymerase (rpoB)

def.defstr: Daptomycin binds to the cytoplasmic membrane of Gram-positive. It's lipopeptide tail servers as a ion channel for potassium. This causes a rapid depolarization that result in failures in DNA/RNA/Protein synthesis. Eventually cell death.

the liaFSR system regulates the cell envelope stress response. It is transcriptionally activated by exposure to alkaline shock, detergents, and particularly antibiotics with lipid II inhibition properties.

MprF is a integral membrane protein that modifies the negatively-charged phosphatidylglycerol on the membrane surface of both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. This confers resistance to cationic peptides that disrupt the cell membrane, including defensins. Mutations in this enzyme can confer additional resistances.

pgsA or phosphatidylglycerophosphate synthetase is an integral membrane protein involved in phospholipid biosynthesis. Inhibition of this enzyme leads to cell death via the inability to form the plasma membrane.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis rpoB mutants conferring resistance to rifampicin

def.defstr: Point mutations that occurs in Mycobacterium tuberculosis rpoB resulting in resistance to rifampicin.

term.name: Mycobacterium leprae rpoB mutations conferring resistance to rifampicin

def.defstr: Point mutations that occurs in Mycobacterium leprae rpoB resulting in resistance to rifampicin

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus rpoB mutants conferring resistance to rifampicin

def.defstr: Point mutations that occurs in Staphylococcus aureus rpoB resulting in resistance to rifampicin

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus rpoB mutants conferring resistance to daptomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations that occurs in Staphylococcus aureus rpoB resulting in resistance to daptomycin

term.name: Escherichia coli rpoB mutants conferring resistance to rifampicin

def.defstr: Point mutations that occurs in Escherichia coli rpoB resulting in resistance to rifampicin

RNA polymerase is a multisubunit enzyme that is necessary for transcription. The beta prime subunit of RNA polymerase forms the active center of the enzyme and template/transcript binding sites. Mutations in rpoC gene confers antibiotic resistance

term.name: daptomycin resistant beta prime subunit of RNA polymerase (rpoC)

def.defstr: Daptomycin resistant RNA polymerases include amino acids substitutions which alter the binding affinity of daptomycin to the protein, resulting in antibiotic resistance.

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus rpoC conferring resistance to daptomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations that occurs in Staphylococcus aureus rpoC resulting in resistance to daptomycin

DNA gyrase is responsible for DNA supercoiling and consists of two alpha and two beta subunits. GyrA point mutations confer resistance by preventing fluoroquinolone antibiotics from binding the alpha-subunit.

term.name: Escherichia coli gyrA conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Point mutation of Escherichia coli gyrA resulted in the lowered affinity between fluoroquinolones and gyrA. Thus, conferring resistance

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis gyrA conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Point mutation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis gyrA resulted in the lowered affinity between fluoroquinolones and gyrA. Thus, conferring resistance.

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus gyrA conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Point mutation of Staphylococcus aureus gyrA resulted in the lowered affinity between fluoroquinolones and gyrA. Thus, conferring resistance.

term.name: Bartonella bacilliformis gyrA conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Point mutation of Bartonella bacilliformis gyrA resulted in the lowered affinity between fluoroquinolones and gyrA. Thus, conferring resistance.

term.name: Mycobaterium leprae gyrA conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Point mutation of Mycobaterium leprae gyrA resulted in the lowered affinity between fluoroquinolones and gyrA. Thus, conferring resistance.

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus gyrB conferring resistance to aminocoumarin

def.defstr: Point mutation in Staphylococcus aureus resulting in aminocoumarin resistance

term.name: Bartonella bacilliformis gyrB conferring resistance to aminocoumarin

def.defstr: Point mutation in Bartonella bacilliformis resulting in aminocoumarin resistance

term.name: Escherichia coli gyrB conferring resistance to aminocoumarin

def.defstr: Point mutation in Escherichia coli resulting in aminocoumarin resistance

term.name: Mycobacterium leprae gyrB conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Mycobacterium leprae gyrB resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance

term.name: Ureaplasma urealyticum gyrB conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Ureaplasma urealyticum resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance

term.name: Morganella morganii gyrB conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Morganella morganii resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance

term.name: Salmonella serovars gyrB conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Salmonella serovars resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance

term.name: Escherichia coli parC conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Escherichia coli parC resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance

term.name: Ureaplasma urealyticum parC conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Ureaplasma urealyticum parC resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance

term.name: Mycoplasma hominis parC conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Mycoplasma hominis parC resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance

term.name: Streptococcus pneumoniae parC conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Streptococcus pneumoniae parC resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus parC conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Staphylococcus aureus parC resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance
ParE is a subunit of topoisomerase IV, necessary for cell survival. Point mutations in ParE prevent fluoroquinolones from inhibiting DNA synthesis, thus conferring resistance.

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus parE conferring resistance to aminocoumarin

def.defstr: Point mutation in Staphylococcus aureus parE resulting in aminocoumarin resistance. Please note: the reference sequence associated with this model corresponds to Staphylococcus aureus MRSA parE, while the SNPs correspond to Staphylococcus aureus RN4220 (for which a complete annotated genome does not exist in genbank at present).

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus parE conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Point mutation in Staphylococcus aureus parE resulting in fluoroquinolones resistance

term.name: Escherichia coli parE conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Point mutation in Escherichia coli parE resulting in fluoroquinolones resistance

term.name: Salmonella serovars parE conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Point mutation in Salmonella serovars parE resulting in fluoroquinolones resistance

term.name: Streptomyces rishiriensis parY mutant conferring resistance to aminocoumarin

def.defstr: point mutation on the Streptomyces rishiriensis parY resulting in aminocoumarin resistance

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus mprF with mutation conferring resistance to daptomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations that occur within Staphylococcus aureus mprF gene resulting in resistance to daptomycin

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus pgsA mutations conferring resistance to daptomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations that occur within Staphylococcus aureus pgsA gene resulting in resistance to daptomycin

MprF is a integral membrane protein that modifies the negatively-charged phosphatidylglycerol on the membrane surface. This confers resistance to cationic peptides that disrupt the cell membrane, including defensins. Additionally, large-scale mutations causing loss of function of the gene result in increased susceptibility to daptomycin.

term.name: Mycobacterium bovis embB mutations conferring resistance to ethambutol

def.defstr: Point mutations that occur within Mycobacterium bovis embB gene resulting in resistance to ethambutol

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis embB mutations conferring resistance to ethambutol

def.defstr: Point mutations that occur within Mycobacterium tuberculosis embB gene resulting in resistance to ethambutol

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis mutant embC conferring resistance to ethambutol

def.defstr: Point mutations in Mycobacterium tuberculosis embC that result in lower affinity between ethambutol and EmbC, resulting in resistance

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsC) mutation conferring resistance to kasugamicin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' minor, 3' major, and central domains in the rrsC 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to kasugamicin
Sequence variants of elongation factor Tu that confer resistance to different classes of antibiotics.

term.name: Clostridium difficile EF-Tu mutants conferring resistance to elfamycin

def.defstr: Sequence variants of Clostridium difficile elongation factor Tu that confer resistance to elfamycin antibiotics.

term.name: Escherichia coli EF-Tu mutants conferring resistance to elfamycin

def.defstr: Sequence variants of Escherichia coli elongation factor Tu that confer resistance to elfamycin antibiotics.

term.name: Streptomyces cinnamoneus EF-Tu mutants conferring resistance to elfamycin

def.defstr: Sequence variants of Streptomyces cinnamoneus elongation factor Tu that confer resistance to elfamycin antibiotics.

term.name: Planobispora rosea EF-Tu mutants conferring resistance to elfamycin

def.defstr: Sequence variants of Planobispora rosea elongation factor Tu that confer resistance to elfamycin antibiotics.

term.name: Planobispora rosea EF-Tu mutants conferring resistance to inhibitor GE2270A

def.defstr: Sequence variants of Planobispora rosea elongation factor Tu that confer resistance to inhibitor GE2270A

term.name: Escherichia coli EF-Tu mutants conferring resistance to kirromycin

def.defstr: Sequence variants of Escherichia coli elongation factor Tu that confer resistance to kirromycin

term.name: Escherichia coli EF-Tu mutants conferring resistance to Pulvomycin

def.defstr: Sequence variants of Escherichia coli elongation factor Tu that confer resistance to Pulvomycin

term.name: Escherichia coli EF-Tu mutants conferring resistance to Enacyloxin IIa

def.defstr: Sequence variants of Escherichia coli elongation factor Tu that confer resistance to Enacyloxin IIa

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsH) mutation conferring resistance to spectinomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' major domain of the rrsH 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to spectinomycin

term.name: Klebsiella pneumoniae acrR with mutation conferring multidrug antibiotic resistance

def.defstr: AcrR is a repressor of the AcrAB-TolC multidrug efflux complex. AcrR mutations result in high level antibiotic resistance.

term.name: Enterobacter aerogenes acrR with mutation conferring multidrug antibiotic resistance

def.defstr: AcrR is a repressor of the AcrAB-TolC multidrug efflux complex. AcrR mutations result in high level antibiotic resistance.

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to spectinomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' major domain of the rrsB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to spectinomycin

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrnB) mutation conferring resistance to spectinomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' major domain of helix 35, in the rrnB gene operon for 16S rRNA of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to spectinomycin

term.name: Escherichia coli marR mutant conferring antibiotic resistance

def.defstr: MarR is a repressor of the mar operon marRAB, thus regulating the expression of marA, the activator of multidrug efflux pump AcrAB.
RamR is a repressor that regulates RamA expression. Mutations lead to the upregulation of AcrAB, which is positively regulated by RamA.
RamR is a repressor that regulates RamA expression. Mutations lead to the upregulation of AcrAB, which is positively regulated by RamA.

term.name: Escherichia coli soxR with mutation conferring antibiotic resistance

def.defstr: SoxR is a sensory protein that upregulates soxS expression in the presence of redox-cycling drugs. This stress response leads to the expression many multidrug efflux pumps.

term.name: Salmonella enterica soxR with mutation conferring antibiotic resistance

def.defstr: SoxR is a sensory protein that upregulates soxS expression in the presence of redox-cycling drugs. This stress response leads to the expression many multidrug efflux pumps.

term.name: Salmonella serovars soxS with mutation conferring antibiotic resistance

def.defstr: SoxS is a global regulator that up-regulates the expression of AcrAB efflux genes. It also reduces OmpF expression to decrease cell membrane permeability.
Mutant forms of the porin Omp36 result in reduced permeability to antibiotics.

term.name: Escherichia coli folP with mutation conferring resistance to sulfonamides

def.defstr: Point mutations in Escherichia coli dihydropteroate synthase folP prevent sulfonamide antibiotics from inhibiting its role in folate synthesis, thus conferring sulfonamide resistance.

term.name: Streptococcus pyogenes folP with mutation conferring resistance to sulfonamides

def.defstr: Point mutations in Streptococcus pyogenes dihydropteroate synthase folP prevent sulfonamide antibiotics from inhibiting its role in folate synthesis, thus conferring sulfonamide resistance.

Dapsone inhibits bacterial synthesis of dihydrofolic acid by competing with with para-aminobenzoate for the active site of dihydropteroate synthetase. Thus acts as a competitive inhibitor of folP. Point mutation within the folP gene results in lowered affinity of dapsone for folP

term.name: Mycobacterium leprae folP with mutation conferring resistance to dapsone

def.defstr: Dapsone inhibits bacterial synthesis of dihydrofolic acid by competing with with para-aminobenzoate for the active site of dihydropteroate synthetase. Point mutation within the Mycobacterium leprae folP gene results in lowered affinity of dapsone for folP.
Mutant forms of the Escherichia coli outer membrane porin OmpF result in reduced permeability to antibiotics.

term.name: mutant porin PIB (por) with reduced permeability to antibiotics

def.defstr: Mutant forms of the porin Por result in reduced permeability to antibiotics, particularly tetracyclines and beta-lactams.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis katG mutations conferring resistance to isoniazid

def.defstr: katG is a catalase-peroxidase that catalyzes the activation of isoniazid. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis, which prevents cell wall synthesis in mycobacteria. Mutations in katG results in inability to activate isoniazid. Over 280 different mutations have been documented in PubMed for katG, with mutations to Ser315 being the most prevalent.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis inhA mutations conferring resistance to isoniazid

def.defstr: inhA is a enoyl-acyl carrier reductase used in lipid metabolism and farry acid biosynthesis. It is inhibited by isoniazid. mutations in the promoter region or multiple copies of the inhA shows marked resistance to isoniazid mediated inhibition of mycolic acid biosynthesis.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis pncA mutations conferring resistance to pyrazinamide

def.defstr: pncA is a pyrazinamidase/nicotinamidase. It catalyzes the activation of pyrazinamide. Some mutation within pncA are associated with loss of enzyme activity, resulting in pyrazinamide resistance.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis rpsL mutations conferring resistance to Streptomycin

def.defstr: Ribosomal protein S12 stabilizes the highly conservednpseudoknot structure formed by 16S rRNA. Amino acidnsubstitutions in RpsL affect the higher-order structure of 16SnrRNA and confer streptomycin resistance by disrupting interactions between 16S rRNA and streptomycin.

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to gentamicin C

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' minor domain of helix 44, in the rrsB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to gentamicin C

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to G418

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' minor domain of helix 44, in the rrsB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to G418

term.name: undecaprenyl pyrophosphate related proteins conferring resistance to bacitracin

def.defstr: Undecaprenyl phosphate is a universal lipid carrier of glycan biosynthetic intermediates for carbohydrate polymers that are exported to the bacterial cell envelope. Antibiotics that targets this compound or proteins associated with the production of this compound leads to cell death.

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to kanamycin A

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' minor domain of helix 44, in the rrsB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to kanamycin A

A sulfone active against a wide range of bacteria but mainly employed for its actions against mycobacterium laprae. Its mechanism of action involves inhibition of folic acid synthesis in susceptible organisms.

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to neomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' minor domain of helix 44, in the rrsB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to neomycin

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to paromomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' minor domain of helix 44, in the rrsB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to paromomycin

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to streptomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 5' domain of helix 18, in the rrsB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to streptomycin

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrnB) mutation conferring resistance to streptomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 5' domain of helix 18, in the rrnB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to streptomycin

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to tobramycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' minor domain of the rrnB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to tobramycin

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to tetracycline

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' major domain of the rrsB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to tetracycline

term.name: Escherichia coli 16S rRNA (rrnB) mutation conferring resistance to tetracycline

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' major domain of the rrnB 16S rRNA gene of Escherichia coli can confer resistance to tetracycline
Dapsone is a sulfone in which it inhibits folic acid synthesis, such as the dihydropteroate synthase.

Pyrazinamide is an Antimycobacterial. It is highly specific and active only against Mycobacterium tuberculosis. This compound is a prodrug and needs to be activated inside the cell. It interferes with the bacterium's ability to synthesize new fatty acids, causing cell death.

LFF571 is a novel semi-synthetic thiopeptide antibiotic derived from GE2270. It has been shown to possess potent in vitro and in vivo activity against Gram-positive bacteria. It is hypothesized that it a translation inhibitor leading to cell death.
Point mutations in dihydropteroate synthase folP prevent sulfonamide antibiotics from inhibiting its role in folate synthesis, thus conferring sulfonamide resistance

Bifunctional enzyme with both catalase and broad-spectrum peroxidase activity. It is a catalase-peroxidases that catalyzes the activation of isoniazid. Mutations that arises within this protein cause changes that results in the inability for katG to activate antibiotics, conferring resistance

inhA is a enoyl-acyl carrier reductase used in lipid metabolism and fatty acid biosynthesis. It is inhibited by isoniazid. Mutations in the promoter region or multiple copies of the inhA shows marked resistance to isoniazid mediated inhibition of mycolic acid biosynthesis.

pncA is a pyrazinamidase/nicotinamidase. It catalyzes the activation of pyrazinamide to pyrazinoic acid. Mutations arise within the pncA gene that caused the loss of pyrazinamidase activity is the major mechanism of antibiotic resistance

Ribosomal protein S12 stabilizes the highly conserved pseudoknot structure formed by 16S rRNA. Amino acid substitutions in RpsL affect the higher-order structure of 16S rRNA and confer antibiotic resistance
pgsA or phosphatidylglycerophosphate synthetase is an integral membrane protein involved in phospholipid biosynthesis. It is a CDP-diacylglycerol-glycerol-3-phosphate 3-phosphatidyltransferase.

Catalyzes the transfer of a lysyl group from L-lysyl-tRNA(Lys) to membrane-bound phosphatidylglycerol (PG), which produces lysylphosphatidylglycerol (LPG), a major component of the bacterial membrane with a positive net charge. LPG synthesis contributes to bacterial virulence as it is involved in the resistance mechanism against cationic antimicrobial peptides (CAMP) produces by the host's immune system (defensins, cathelicidins) and by the competing microorganisms (bacteriocins)
Arabinosyl transferases allow for the polymerization of arabinose to form arabinan. Arabanan is required for formation of mycobacterial cell walls
Key enzyme in folate metabolism. Catalyzes an essential reaction for de novo glycine and purine synthesis, and for DNA precursor synthesis
inhA is a enoyl-acyl carrier reductase used in lipid metabolism and fatty acid biosynthesis.
Porin proteins permeable to antibiotics.

term.name: antibiotic sensitive beta-prime subunit of RNA polymerase (rpoC)

def.defstr: RNA polymerase is a multisubunit enzyme that is necessary for transcription. The beta-prime subunit of RNA polymerase forms the active center of the enzyme and template/transcript binding sites. This enzyme can be inactivated by antibiotics leading to cell death.
ParE is a subunit of topoisomerase IV, necessary for cell survival. Point mutations in ParE prevent fluoroquinolones from inhibiting DNA synthesis, thus conferring resistance.
Ribosomal protein S12 stabilizes the highly conserved pseudoknot structure formed by 16S rRNA. It is targeted and inhibited by streptomycin
Enzymes, other proteins or other gene products shown clinically to confer resistance to the antibiotic drug, isoniazid.
Enzymes, other proteins or other gene products shown clinically to confer resistance to the antibiotic drug pyrazinamide.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to kanamycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' domain of 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis can confer resistance to kanamycin.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to viomycin

def.defstr: Peptide antibiotics inhibit protein synthesis. Resistance to viomycin can be caused by an altered RNA molecule in the 16S ribosomal subunit.

term.name: Enterococcus faecium EF-Tu mutants conferring resistance to GE2270A

def.defstr: Sequence variants of Enterococcus faecium elongation factor Tu that confer resistance to GE2270A

term.name: antibiotic sensitive RNA polymerase switch region

def.defstr: The switch region is a structural element that mediates conformational changes and contacts required for RNAP to load DNA into the RNAP active-center cleft during transcription initiation. The switch region is located at the base of the RNAP "clamp" and serves as the "hinge" that mediates opening of the RNAP clamp to load DNA into the RNAP active-center cleft and mediates closing of the RNAP clamp to retain DNA in the RNAP active-center cleft.
A foreign PBP2 acquired by lateral gene transfer that able to perform peptidoglycan synthesis in the presence of beta-lactams.

CfrA is a chloramphenicol-florfenicol resistance gene and methyltransferase enzyme. Methylation of position 8 of A2503 in 23S rRNA confers resistance to chloramphenicol antibiotics. Additional Oxazolidinone resistance mediated by the cfr gene in a human isolated was first reported from Colombia in linezolid- and methicillin-resistant staphylocci. Described by Arias et al. 2008.

tlyA encodes for hemolysin. It Catalyzes the 2'-O-methylation at nucleotides C1409 in 16S rRNA and C1920 in 23S rRNA. Mutation that arise within this gene reduces the binding affinity of aminoglycosides to rRNA

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis tlyA mutations conferring resistance to aminoglycosides

def.defstr: Specific mutations that arise in Mycobacterium tuberculosis tlyA resulting in aminoglycosides resistance

iniA, an isoniazid-induced protein, is part of the iniBAC operon that participates in the development of tolerance to both isoniazid and ethambutol. May function through a MDR-pump like mechanism, although it does not appear to directly transport isoniazid from the cell
Mutations that occurs on the iniA genes resulting in the resistance to ethambutol

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis iniA mutant conferring resistance to Ethambutol

def.defstr: Specific mutations in Mycobacterium tuberculosis iniA resulting in resistance to ethambutol

iniC, an isoniazid-induced protein, is part of the iniBAC operon that participates in the development of tolerance to both isoniazid and ethambutol. May function through a MDR-pump like mechanism, although it does not appear to directly transport isoniazid from the cell
Mutations that occurs on the iniC genes resulting in the resistance to ethambutol

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis iniC mutant conferring resistance to ethambutol

def.defstr: Specific mutations that occurs on Mycobacterium tuberculosis iniC causing it to be ethambutol resistant.
Mutations that occurs on the embA genes resulting in the resistance to ethambutol

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis embA mutant conferring resistance to ethambutol

def.defstr: Specific mutations that occurs on Mycobacterium tuberculosis embA leading to the lowered affinity of ethambutol to embA
Mutations that occurs on the embR genes resulting in the resistance to ethambutol

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis embR mutant conferring resistance to ethambutol

def.defstr: Point mutation in the M.tuberculosis embR results in increased resistance to ethambutol

Monooxygenase able to convert a wide range of ketones to the corresponding esters or lactones via a Baeyer-Villiger oxidation reaction. It is responsible for the activation of several thiocarbamide-containing pro-drugs into cytotoxic species
Mutations that occurs on the ethA genes resulting in the inability to catalyzes the oxidation of ethionamide (ETH) to the corresponding sulfoxide (the active drug)

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis ethA with mutation conferring resistance to ethionamide

def.defstr: Specific mutations that occurs on Mycobacterium tuberculosis ethA causing it to be ethionamide resistant

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis gyrB mutant conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Mycobacterium tuberculosis gyrB resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance

ndh is a NADH oxidase. It participates in antibiotic resistance by diminishing NADH oxidation and consequently causes an increase in NADH concentration and depletion of NAD+. This alteration of the NADH/NAD+ ratio prevents the peroxidation reactions required for the activation of INH, as well as the displacement of the NADH-isonicotinic acyl complex from InhA enzyme binding site.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis ndh with mutation conferring resistance to isoniazid

def.defstr: Point mutations in the Mycobacterium tuberculosis ndh gene shown clinically to confer resistance to isoniazid.

kasA is a ketoacyl acyl carrier protein synthase that catalyzes the condensation reaction of fatty acid synthesis by the addition to an acyl acceptor of two carbons from malonyl-ACP. It is involved in elongation of fatty acids intermediate in the biosynthetic pathway of mycolic acids.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis kasA mutant conferring resistance to isoniazid

def.defstr: Specific mutations on the Mycobacterium tuberculosis kasA gene resulting in lowered affinity of isoniazid, resulting in resistance

Arabinosyl transferases allow for the polymerization of arabinose to form arabinan. Arabanan is required for formation of mycobacterial cell walls and arabinosyltransferases are targets of the drug ethambutol. Mutations in these genes can confer resistance to rifampicin.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis embB mutants conferring resistance to rifampicin

def.defstr: Specific mutations that occurs on Mycobacterium tuberculosis embB causing it to be rifampicin resistant
GidB is a m7G methyltransferase specific for 16S rRNA. Mutations within the gidB gene causes changes in the structure or 16s rRNA, leading to resistance to aminoglycosides

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis gidB mutation conferring resistance to streptomycin

def.defstr: Specific mutations that occurs on Mycobacterium tuberculosis gidB causing it to be streptomycin resistant
wildtype embR sensitive to antibiotics. It is an arabinosyltransferase involved in lipoarabinomannan synthesis.
ethionamide is a second-line antitubercular agent that inhibits mycolic acid synthesis

ethA is a Monooxygenase that is able to convert a wide range of ketones to the corresponding esters or lactones via a Baeyer-Villiger oxidation reaction. Is responsible for the activation of several thiocarbamide-containing pro-drugs into cytotoxic species.
It Catalyzes the 2'-O-methylation at nucleotides C1409 in 16S rRNA and C1920 in 23S rRNA.
GidB is a m7G methyltransferase specific for 16S rRNA.

kasA is a ketoacyl acyl carrier protein synthase that catalyzes the condensation reaction of fatty acid synthesis by the addition to an acyl acceptor of two carbons from malonyl-ACP. It is involved in elongation of fatty acids intermediate in the biosynthetic pathway of mycolic acids.

TetR is the repressor of the tetracycline resistance element; its N-terminal region forms a helix-turn-helix structure and binds DNA. Binding of tetracycline to TetR reduces the repressor affinity for the tetracycline resistance gene (tetA) promoter operator sites. Mutations arise within tetR results in lower affinity for tetracyclin

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to streptomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations within the 530 loop of the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis can result in resistance against streptomycin. These mutations do not directly inhibit the binding of streptomycin, but is hypothesized that they interfere with conformational perturbations that account for streptomycin's action on the ribosome.

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to amikacin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' domain of 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis can confer resistance to amikacin.

term.name: Chlamydophila psittaci 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to spectinomycin

def.defstr: Point mutation in the 16S rRNA helix 34 region of Chlamydophila psittaci can confer resistance against spectinomycin

term.name: Pasteurella multocida 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to spectinomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the helix 34 region of 16S rRNA of Pasteurella multocida can confer resistance to spectinomycin

term.name: Neisseria gonorrhoeae 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to spectinomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the helix 34 region of 16S rRNA of Neisseria gonorrhoeae can confer resistance against spectinomycin

term.name: Neisseria meningitidis 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to spectinomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Neisseria meningitidis can confer resistance to spectinomycin

term.name: Propionibacterium acnes 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to tetracycline

def.defstr: Tetracycline binds tightly to the helix 34 domain in 16S rRNA, where it interferes sterically with the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the ribosome A site to block protein synthesis. Mutations in the nucleotide sequence in this domain for Propionibacterium acnes can result in resistance against tetracycline.

term.name: Borrelia burgdorferi 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to spectinomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' major domain of the 16S rRNA gene of Borrelia burgdorferi can confer resistance to spectinomycin

term.name: Borrelia burgdorferi 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to kanamycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' minor domain of the 16S rRNA gene of Borrelia burgdorferi can confer resistance to kanamycin

term.name: Borrelia burgdorferi 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to gentamicin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 3' minor domain of the 16S rRNA gene of Borrelia burgdorferi can confer resistance to gentamicin

term.name: Helicobacter pylori 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to tetracycline

def.defstr: Tetracycline binds tightly to the helix 34 domain in 16S rRNA, where it interferes sterically with the binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the ribosome A site to block protein synthesis. Mutations in the nucleotide sequence in this domain of Helicobacter pylori can result in resistance against tetracycline.

term.name: Escherichia coli soxS with mutation conferring antibiotic resistance

def.defstr: SoxS is a global regulator that up-regulates the expression of AcrAB efflux genes. It also reduces OmpF expression to decrease cell membrane permeability.

term.name: Salmonella enterica 16S rRNA (rrsD) mutation conferring resistance to spectinomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the helix 34 region of the rrsD 16S rRNA gene of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium can confer resistance to spectinomycin

term.name: Mycobacterium chelonae 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to amikacin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium chelonae can cause resistance to amikacin.

term.name: Mycobacterium chelonae 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to kanamycin A

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium chelonae can cause resistance to kanamycin A.

term.name: Mycobacterium chelonae 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to tobramycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium chelonae can cause resistance to tobramycin.

term.name: Mycobacterium chelonae 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to gentamicin C

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium chelonae can confer resistance to gentamicin C

term.name: Mycobacterium chelonae 16S rRNA mutation conferring resistance to neomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of Mycobacterium chelonae can cause resistance to neomycin.
Sensitive form of 16s susceptable to antibiotics

Sensitive form of 16s susceptable to antibiotics

def.defstr: Sensitive form of 16s susceptable to antibiotics
Sensitive form of 16s susceptable to antibiotics

term.name: determinant of resistance to polyamine antibiotics

def.defstr: Enzymes, other proteins or other gene products shown clinically to confer resistance to polyamine antibiotics.

term.name: Mycobacterium smegmatis 16S rRNA (rrsA) mutation conferring resistance to hygromycin B

def.defstr: Point mutations in the highly conserved helix 44 of the 16S rrsA rRNA gene of Mycobacterium smegmatis can confer resistance to hygromycin B. Resistance against hygromycin B is the result of conformational alterations that distorts a strong hydrogen bond leading to a change in the local geometry of the hygromycin B binding site.

term.name: Mycobacterium smegmatis 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to hygromycin B

def.defstr: Point mutations in the highly conserved helix 44 of the 16S rrsB rRNA gene of Mycobacterium smegmatis can confer resistance to hygromycin B. Resistance against hygromycin B is the result of conformational alterations that distorts a strong hydrogen bond leading to a change in the local geometry of the hygromycin B binding site.

term.name: Mycobacterium smegmatis 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to streptomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the helix 44 region of the 16S rRNA rrsB gene of Mycobacterium smegmatis can confer resistance to streptomycin

term.name: Mycobacterium smegmatis 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to kanamycin A

def.defstr: Point mutations in the helix 44 region of the 16S rRNA rrsB gene of Mycobacterium smegmatis can confer resistance to kanamycin A

term.name: Mycobacterium smegmatis 16S rRNA (rrsA) mutation conferring resistance to kanamycin A

def.defstr: Point mutations in the helix 44 region of the 16S rRNA rrsA gene of Mycobacterium smegmastis can confer resistance to kanamycin A

term.name: Mycobacterium smegmatis 16S rRNA (rrsA) mutation conferring resistance to neomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the helix 44 region of the 16S rRNA rrsA gene of Mycobacterium smegmatis can confer resistance to neomycin

term.name: Mycobacterium smegmatis 16S rRNA (rrsA) mutation conferring resistance to viomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the helix 44 region of the 16S rRNA rrsA gene of Mycobacterium smegmatis can confer resistance to viomycin.

term.name: Mycobacterium smegmatis 16S rRNA (rrsB) mutation conferring resistance to viomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations in the helix 44 region of the 16S rRNA rrsB gene of Mycobacterium smegmatis can confer resistance to viomycin.
Multidrug resistance efflux pump. Could be involved in resistance to puromycin, acriflavine and tetraphenylarsonium chloride.
Multidrug resistance efflux pump. Could be involved in resistance to puromycin, acriflavine and tetraphenylarsonium chloride
Multidrug resistance efflux pump. Could be involved in resistance to puromycin, acriflavine and tetraphenylarsonium chloride

A multidrug efflux pump from Enterococcus faecalis. There exist efflux activity of several antimicrobial agents such as DAPI, Hoechst 33342 and acriflavine. Efflux of DAPI via EmeA was strongly inhibited by reserpine.

FusB encodes a 2-domain zinc-binding protein that binds the ribosomal translocase EF-G, causing it to dissociate from the ribosome. This action increases the ribosomal turnover rate and confers resistance to fusidic acid.
CEPS is a typical class C cephalosporinase found in Aeromonas sobria, first isolated from strain 163a.
Major facilitator superfamily transporter. Resistance to tetracenomycin C by an active tetracenomycin C efflux system which is probably energized by transmembrane electrochemical gradients.
This enzyme breaks the beta-lactam antibiotic ring open and deactivates the molecule's antibacterial properites.
This enzyme breaks the beta-lactam antibiotic ring open and deactivates the molecule's antibacterial properties.
This enzyme breaks the beta-lactam antibiotic ring open and deactivates the molecule's antibacterial properties.
Class A beta-lactamase found in Yersinia enterocolitica biovar 1A
A beta-lactamase found in Bacteroides fragilis producing either low or high levels of the endogenous cephalosporinase activity
Sed-1 is a chromosomal-encoded class A beta-lactamase identified in Citrobacter sedlakii.
Class A beta-lactamase found in Mycobacterium fortuitum
Class A beta lactamase found in Rhodopseudomonas capsulata
Class A beta-lactamase found in Streptomyces albus G
Class A beta-lactamase found in Actinomadura R39
Magainins A are antimicrobial peptides produced by amphibians as part of their innate immune system.
magainin B is is a synthetic analog of magainin 1, an antimicrobial peptide
magainin G is is a synthetic analog of magainin 1, an antimicrobial peptide. It differs from magainin B by the addition of an beta-alanine at the N terminal
magainin H is is a synthetic analog of magainin 1, an antimicrobial peptide. It differs from magainin B with the substitution of D-alanine instead of L-alanine.
Magainin1 is an antimicrobial peptides produced by amphibians as part of their innate immune system. It is derived from the Xenopus laevis.
Magainin 2 is an antimicrobial peptides produced from Xenopus laevis skin. It induce osmotic lysis of bacteria

The LpxA gene is widely known to be involved in the biosynthesis of lipid A in Gram-negative bacteria and mutations to this gene may cause resistance to antimicrobial peptides that target the outer membrane

The LpxC gene is widely known to be involved in the biosynthesis of lipid A in Gram-negative bacteria and mutations to this gene may cause resistance to antimicrobial peptides that target the outer membrane

The LpxD gene is widely known to be involved in the biosynthesis of lipid A in Gram-negative bacteria and mutations to this gene may cause resistance to antimicrobial peptides that target the outer membrane

PmrC mediates the modification of Lipid A by the addition of 4-amino-4-deoxy-L-arabinose (L-Ara4N) and phosphoethanolamine, resulting in a less negative cell membrane and decreased binding of polymyxin B.

PmrE is required for the synthesis and transfer of 4-amino-4-deoxy-L-arabinose (Ara4N) to Lipid A, which allows gram-negative bacteria to resist the antimicrobial activity of cationic antimicrobial peptides and antibiotics such as polymyxin

PmrF is required for the synthesis and transfer of 4-amino-4-deoxy-L-arabinose (Ara4N) to Lipid A, which allows gram-negative bacteria to resist the antimicrobial activity of cationic antimicrobial peptides and antibiotics such as polymyxin. pmrF corresponds to 1 locus in Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 and 1 locus in Pseudomonas aeruginosa LESB58.
BasRS is a two-component regulatory system. BasR is phosphorylated by BasS at high[Fe3+] levels. The BasRS system regulates the expression of pmrE, pmrF and pmrC, leading to antibiotic resistance
Genes involved in alteration of the cell wall overall charge, leading to antimicrobial resistance due to reduced binding

term.name: Acinetobacter mutant Lpx gene conferring resistance to colistin

def.defstr: These genes are involved in the biosynthesis of lipid A in Gram-negative bacteria and mutations to this gene may cause resistance to antimicrobial peptides that target the outer membrane. Mutation by absence or insertion of ISAba11 sequence is a known cause of resistance in Acinetobacter baumanniib?.
Response regulator for Lipid A modification genes; two-component system involved in polymyxin resistance that senses high extracellular Fe(2+)
Histidine protein kinase sensor Lipid A modification gene; part of a two-component system involved in polymyxin resistance that senses high extracellular Fe(2+)

term.name: Klebsiella mutant PhoP conferring antibiotic resistance to colistin

def.defstr: A mutant phoP activates pmrHFIJKLM expression responsible for L-aminoarabinose synthesis and polymyxin resistance, by way of alteration of negative charge

The loss or reduction of the net negative charge within the cell wall of gram negative bacteria is a mechanism of resistance for cationic antimicrobials that depend on the negative charge for binding to the surface
NmcA is a class A serine beta-lactamase isolated from Enterobacter cloacae.
From the Lahey list of beta-lactamases, not yet released.
From the Lahey list of beta-lactamases, not yet released.

NmcR is a homolog of the LysR regulator found in Enterobacter cloacae that contribute to the regulation of NmcA beta-lactamase

term.name: 16s rRNA with mutation conferring resistance to aminoglycoside antibiotics

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of bacteria can confer resistance to aminoglycosides.

term.name: 16s rRNA with mutation conferring resistance to peptide antibiotics

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of bacteria can confer resistance to peptide antibiotics.

term.name: 16s rRNA with mutation conferring resistance to polyamine antibiotics

def.defstr: Point mutations in the 16S rRNA of bacteria can confer resistance to polyamine antibiotics.

term.name: 16S rRNA with mutation conferring resistance to tetracycline derivatives

def.defstr: Point mutations in the bacterial 16S rRNA region shown clinically to confer resistance to tetracycline and tetracycline derivatives (polyketide antibiotics).
PEDO-1 is a subclass B3 metallo-beta lactamase isolated from Pedobacter roseus exhibiting resistance to carbapenems.

Plazomicin is a neoglycoside, or "next-generation" aminoglycoside, that has been identified as a potentially useful agent to combat drug-resistant bacteria, such as Acinetobacter baumannii and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
AAC(6')-Ib' is an aminoglycoside acetyltransferase encoded by plasmids, transposons, integrons in P. aeruginosa and P. fluorescens.
AAC(6')-Iaj is a functional acetyltransferase that modifies the amino groups at the 6' positions of aminoglycosides and contributes to aminoglycoside resistance of P. aeruginosa

TriABC-OpmH is a triclosan-specific efflux pump expressed in the Gram-negative Pseudomonas aeruginosa. TriABC is the only P. aeruginosa resistance nodulation cell division (RND) pump which contains two membrane fusion proteins, TriA and TriB, and both are required for efflux pump function. TriABC associated with OpmH assemble a functional triclosan efflux pump.
TriA is a membrane protein that is fused to TriB and both are required for the triclosan efflux pump function of TriABC-OpmH in P. aeruginosa.
TriB is a membrane protein that is fused to TriA and both are required for the triclosan efflux pump function of TriABC-OpmH in P. aeruginosa.
TriC is a resistance nodulation cell division (RND) transporter that is a part of TriABC-OpmH, a triclosan-specific efflux protein.
OpmH is an outer membrane efflux protein required for triclosan-specific efflux pump function.

term.name: Pseudomonas aeruginosa gyrA conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Point mutation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa gyrA resulted in the lowered affinity between fluoroquinolones and gyrA. Thus, conferring resistance.

term.name: Pseudomonas aeruginosa parE conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Point mutation in Pseudomonas aeruginosa parE resulting in sensitivity to fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin). In combination with a gyrase mutation (gyrA or gyrB), it confers a high level of resistance to ciprofloxacin.

term.name: Pseudomonas aeruginosa oprD with mutation conferring resistance to imipenem

def.defstr: oprD is an outer membrane porin which facilitates the uptake of basic amino acids and imipenem in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
APH(3')-VI is an aminoglycoside phosphoryltransferase that acts on the 3-OH of target of aminoglycosides.
PvrR is a response regulator that controls the conversion between antibiotic-resistant and antibiotic-susceptible forms of Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms through porin deletion/gene absence

MCR-1 is a plasmid-borne phosphoethanolamine transferase that interferes with binding of colistin to the cell membrane via addition of phosphoethanolamine to lipid A, resulting reduction in negative charge of the cell membrane.

Sitafloxacin is a fluoroquinolone active against multi-resistant Gram-positive and negative pathogens. Sitafloxacin shows inhibitory activity against DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, which blocks bacterial DNA replication, thereby causing double-stranded breaks in the bacterial chromosome.

MexJK-OpmH is a triclosan efflux protein expressed in the Gram-negative Pseudomonas aeruginosa. MexJ is the membrane fusion protein, MexK is the inner membrane resistance-nodulation-cell division (RND) transporter, and OpmH is the outer membrane efflux protein. MexJK is constitutively expressed in mexL mutants.
mexJ is the membrane fusion protein of the MexJK multidrug efflux protein.
mexK is the inner membrane resistance-nodulation-cell division (RND) transporter in the MexJK multidrug efflux protein.

MexJK-OprM is a multidrug efflux protein expressed in the Gram-negative Pseudomonas aeruginosa. MexJ is the membrane fusion protein, MexK is the inner membrane resistance-nodulation-cell division (RND) transporter, and OprM is the outer membrane factor protein.
Enzymes, other proteins or other gene products shown clinically to confer resistance to the antibacterial biocide triclosan.
MexPQ-OpmE multidrug efflux pump expressed in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. MexP is the membrane fusion protein; MexQ is the inner membrane transporter; and OpmE is the outer membrane channel.
MexP is the membrane fusion protein of the MexPQ-OpmE multidrug efflux complex
MexQ is the inner membrane transporter of the multidrug efflux pump MexPQ-OpmE.
opmE is an outer membrane factor protein that is part of the multidrug efflux pump MexPQ-OpmE.
Rokitamycin is a macrolide antibiotic. Synthesized from strains of Streptomyces kitasatoensis.

term.name: Pseudomonas aeruginosa gyrA and parC conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Point mutation in Pseudomonas aeruginosa parC resulting in fluoroquinolone resistance also requiring a gyrA mutation.
MexMN-OprM is a multidrug efflux pump expressed in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. MexM is the membrane fusion protein; MexN is the inner membrane transporter; and OprM is the outer membrane channel.
mexM is the membrane fusion protein of the MexMN-OprM multidrug efflux complex.
MexN is the inner membrane transporter of the MexMN-OprM multidrug efflux complex.

Penems are a class of unsaturated beta-lactam antibiotics with a broad spectrum of antibacterial activity and have a structure which renders them highly resistant to beta-lactamases. All penems are all synthetically made and act by inhibiting the synthesis of the peptidoglycan layer of bacterial cell walls. They are structurally similar to carbapenems, however, where carbapenems have a carbon, penems have a sulfur.
Faropenem is an orally active beta-lactam antibiotic belonging to the penem group.

Panipenem is a carbapenem antibacterial agent with a broad spectrum of in vitro activity covering a wide range of Gram-negative and Gram-positive aerobic and anaerobic bacterial. It is used in combination with betamipron to inhibit panipenem uptake into the renal tubule and prevent nephrotoxicity.
MexZ is a transcriptional regulator that downregulates the mexXY multidrug transporter operon, which confers to aminoglycoside resistance on Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
MexL is a specific repressor of mexJK transcription and autoregulates its own expression.
VEB-1a is a beta-lactamase that is found in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
VEB-1b is a beta-lactamase that is found in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
VCC-1 is a Class A carbapenemase isolated from Vibrio cholerae and exhibits resistance to penicillins, carbapenems and monobactam antibiotics.
PEDO-2 is a subclass B3 metallo-beta lactamase isolated from Pedobacter borealis exhibiting carbapenem resistance.
PEDO-3 is a class B1 metallo-beta lactamase isolated from Pedobacter kyungheensis exhibiting resistance to carbapenems.
CPS-1 is a subclass B3 metallo-beta lactamase isolated from Chyseobacterium piscium exhibiting carbapenem resistance.
ESP-1 is a subclass B3 metallo-beta lactamase isolated from Epilithonimonas tenax conferring resistance to carbapenems.
MSI-1 is a subclass B3 metallo-beta lactamase isolated from Massilia oculi conferring resistance to carbapenems.
MSI-OXA is an OXA-85-like class D beta lactamase isolated from Massilia oculi.
SPG-1 is a subclass B3 metallo-beta lactamase isolated from Sphingomonas sp.

This inducible cluster confers high resistance to vancomycin and intermediate resistance to teicoplanin. It achieves this through peptidoglycan restructuring with its VanA ligase homologue, VanI, causing the precursurs to end in D-Ala-D-Lac. The cluster uniquely contains murF, the final enzyme in the synthesis of UDP-N-acetylmuramoyl-pentapeptide, the precursor of murein. The VanI gene cluster has been found in chromosomal DNA. Gene orientation: vanSRIWK-murFvanX

VanI is a D-Ala-D-Lac ligase that reduces vancomycin binding affinity, helping to confer vancomycin resistance as part of the VanI resistance gene cluster in Desulfitobacterium spp. and Desulfosporosinus spp.
VanWI is a vanW variant found in the vanI gene cluster
VanXI is a VanX variant found in the VanI glycopeptide resistance gene cluster. It is a D-Ala-D-Ala dipeptidase.
VanSI is a vanS variant found in the vanI gene cluster; it is a histidine kinase.
VanKI is a peptidoglycan bridge formation protein also known as FemAB that is part of the VanI glycopeptide resistance gene cluster.
VanRI is the regulatory transcriptional activator in the VanSR regulator within the VanI glycopeptide resistance gene cluster.
A specific fusidic acid resistance gene conferring intrinsic resistance in the bacteria Staphylococcus saprophyticus.

FusC is a fusidic acid resistance gene enabling ribosomal translocase EF-G dissociation from the ribosome that has been detected in Staphylococcus aureus and Staphylococcus intermedius. Its mechanism is believed to be similar to fusB due to its high level of sequence homology.
Antibiotic resistant fusA is caused by mutations to the elongation factor G (EF-G) and confers resistance to fusidic acid.

term.name: Staphylococcus mutant fusA gene conferring resistance to fusidic acid

def.defstr: The mutations to this gene are involved in altering the translation elongation factor G (EF-G) in association with the ribosome to prevent fusidic acid from binding EF-G and preventing translation.
Antibiotic resistant fusE is caused by mutations in a region of the rplF gene encoding riboprotein L6, and confers resistance to fusidic acid.

term.name: Staphylococcus mutant fusE gene conferring resistance to fusidic acid

def.defstr: The mutations to the rplF gene encoding riboprotein L6 have been shown to cause fusidic acid resistance, demonstrating a potential secondary site of action of the antibiotic that is blocked through these mutations. Several types of mutations have been identified that cause resistance, including SNPs, frameshift mutations and early stop codons.
The mphD gene codes for a macrolide 2'-phosphotransferase partial sequence detected in Pseudomonas aeruginosa that provides a high level of resistance to all 14- and 15-membered-ring macrolides.
The mphG gene encodes a macrolide 2'-phosphotransferase found in Photobacterium damselae sharing sequence similarity to mphA in E. coli.
vatF is a streptogramin A acetyl transferase gene isolated from the chromosome of Yersinia enterocolitica.
lnuE encodes a lincosamide resistance gene isolated from Streptococcus suis that was truncated by an ISEnfa5-cfr-ISEnfa5 segment insertion. It shares the closest sequence similarity to lnuA.
mefC is a macrolide efflux gene isolated from a plasmid in Photobacterium damselae.
optrA encodes an ABC-transporter gene conferring resistance to oxazolidinones that was isolated from a plasmid in Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus faecium.
Enzymes, other proteins or other gene products shown clinically to confer resistance to oxazolidinone (ie., linezolid) antibiotics.
oleC is an ABC transporter isolated from Streptomyces antibioticus and is involved in oleandomycin secretion.
salA is an ABC transporter gene isolated from the chromosome of Staphylococcus sciuri conferring resistance to lincosamides and streptogramins.

term.name: Escherichia coli nfsA mutations conferring resistance to nitrofurantoin

def.defstr: nfsA encodes the major oxygen-insesitive nitroreductase in E. coli. The first step of resistance to nitrofurazone is mutation of nfsA.
eatAv is a mutated form of the wildtype eatA ABC transporter gene isolated from Enterococcus faecium conferring resistance to lincosamides, streptogramin A's and pleuromutilins (LSaP phenotype).
Enzymes, other proteins or other gene products shown clinically to confer resistance to pleuromutilin antibiotics.

The nfsA-encoded nitroreductase is the major oxygen-insensitive nitroreductase present in E. coli. NfsA uses only NADPH and has broad electron acceptor specificity. Mutations in nfsA cause resistance to nitrofurazone and furazolidone. Resistance to nitrofurantoin via mutation of nfsA reduces the fitness of clinical isolates of E. coli.

nsfB encodes a minor oxygen-insensitive nitroreductase. NfsB reduces a broad range of nitroaromatic compounds including the antibiotics nitrofurazone and nitrofurantoin. NfsB is a flavin mononucleotide (FMN)-containing protein and uses both NADH and NADPH as a source of reducing equivalents. Mutations in nfsB lead to increased resistance to nitrofurazone and furazolidone in an nfsA mutant background.

term.name: Escherichia coli nfsB mutations conferring resistance to nitrofurantoin

def.defstr: nfsB encodes the minor oxygen-insesitive nitroreductase in E. coli. The first step of resistance to nitrofurazone is mutation of nfsA, while the increased resistance associated with second step mutants is a consequence of nfsB mutation.

term.name: Enterococcus faecalis cls conferring resistance to daptomycin

def.defstr: cls or cardiolipin synthase is an inner membrane protein involved in membrane synthesis and phosopholipid metabolism, with mutations to the gene being capable of conferring daptomycin resistance.

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus ileS with mutation conferring resistance to mupirocin

def.defstr: Point mutations to the isoleucyl-tRNA synthetase (ileS) in Staphylococcus aureus that confer resistance to mupirocin.

term.name: Bifidobacteria intrinsic ileS conferring resistance to mupirocin

def.defstr: Bifidobacteria have an intrinsically resistant form of ileS (isoleucyl-tRNA synthetase) that confers resistance to mupirocin.
Enzymes, other proteins or other gene products shown clinically to confer resistance to the antibiotic drug, nitrofurantoin
Mechanism of antibiotic resistance conferred by deletion of gene (usually a porin)
Bacillus Cluster B mph are chromosomally-encoded macrolide phosphotransferases that inactivate 14-, 15- and 16-membered macrolides.
Deletion of gene or gene product results in resistance. For example, deletion of a porin gene blocks drug from entering the cell.

MprF is a integral membrane protein that modifies the negatively-charged phosphatidylglycerol on the membrane surface. This confers resistance to cationic peptides that disrupt the cell membrane, including defensins.

MprF is a integral membrane protein that modifies the negatively-charged phosphatidylglycerol on the membrane surface. This confers resistance to cationic peptides that disrupt the cell membrane, including defensins.

MprF is a integral membrane protein that modifies the negatively-charged phosphatidylglycerol on the membrane surface. This confers resistance to cationic peptides that disrupt the cell membrane, including defensins.

MprF is a integral membrane protein that modifies the negatively-charged phosphatidylglycerol on the membrane surface. This confers resistance to cationic peptides that disrupt the cell membrane, including defensins.

MprF is a integral membrane protein that modifies the negatively-charged phosphatidylglycerol on the membrane surface. This confers resistance to cationic peptides that disrupt the cell membrane, including defensins.

term.name: Escherichia coli murA with mutation conferring resistance to fosfomycin

def.defstr: murA or UDP-N-acetylglucosamine enolpyruvyl transferase catalyses the initial step in peptidoglycan biosynthesis and is inhibited by fosfomycin. Overexpression of murA through mutations such as Asp369Asn and Leu370Ile confers fosfomycin resistance. Extensive evidence has shown the significance of C115 mutations in conferring fosfomycin resistance since this residue represents a primary binding site for the antibiotic across many species.

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus murA with mutation conferring resistance to fosfomycin

def.defstr: murA or UDP-N-acetylglucosamine enolpyruvyl transferase catalyses the initial step in peptidoglycan biosynthesis and is inhibited by fosfomycin. Overexpression of murA through mutations confers fosfomycin resistance.

term.name: Borrelia burgdorferi murA with mutation conferring resistance to fosfomycin

def.defstr: murA or UDP-N-acetylglucosamine enolpyruvyl transferase catalyses the initial step in peptidoglycan biosynthesis and is inhibited by fosfomycin. Mutations to the murA enzyme confers resistance to the antibiotic.

term.name: Mycobacterium smegmatis mutant ndh conferring resistance to isoniazid

def.defstr: Mutations in the Mycobacterium smegmatis ndh gene that results in increased resistance to isoniazid.

term.name: Mycobacterium bovis mutant ndh conferring resistance to isoniazid

def.defstr: Mutations in the Mycobacterium bovis ndh gene that results in increased resistance to isoniazid.

A heterocyclic antibiotic that targets mutant gyrA (type II topoisomerase) containing an S84L substitution, counteracting acquired quinolone resistance. It is effective against quinolone-resistant Gram-positive bacteria including S. aureus and E. faecalis. Due to its ability to counteract quinolone resistance by targeting the mutant form of the gyrA protein, it is classified as a reverse antibiotic (RA).

term.name: Mycobacterium tuberculosis intrinsic murA conferring resistance to fosfomycin

def.defstr: Mycobacterium tuberculosis murA confers intrinsic resistance to fosfomycin. The presence of an aspartic acid residue in place of the critical cysteine at position 117 that enables fosfomycin binding is believed to be responsible for this intrinsic resistance.

term.name: Chlamydia trachomatis intrinsic murA conferring resistance to fosfomycin

def.defstr: Chlamydia murA confers intrinsic resistance to fosfomycin. The presence of an aspartic acid residue in place of the critical cysteine at position 119 that enables fosfomycin binding is believed to be responsible for this intrinsic resistance.
Inherent parC resistance to fluoroquinolone from an antibiotic producer. The presence of these genes confers self-resistance to the antibiotic it produces.
Inherent ParY resistant to aminocoumarin from an antibiotic producer. The presence of these genes confers self resistance to the antibiotic it produces

term.name: Bacillus subtilis pgsA mutations conferring resistance to daptomycin

def.defstr: Point mutations that occur within the Bacillus subtilis pgsA gene resulting in resistance to daptomycin.

term.name: Campylobacter jejuni gyrA conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Campylobacter jejuni is a major bacterial infectious agent associated with gastroenteritis. Quinolone resistance is reportedly conferred by a single C-257-T nucleotide substitution in the gyrA gene.

term.name: Enterococcus faecium liaF mutant conferring daptomycin resistance

def.defstr: liaF is an accessory protein that acts as a negative regulator of liaRS signal transduction pathway. Mutations confer daptomycin resistance.

term.name: Enterococcus faecalis liaS mutant conferring daptomycin resistance

def.defstr: liaS is a histidine kinase found in the liaFSR signal transduction pathway. Mutations confer daptomycin resistance.

term.name: Enterococcus faecalis liaR mutant conferring daptomycin resistance

def.defstr: liaR is a response regulator found in the liaFSR signal transduction pathway. Mutations confer daptomycin resistance.

Plasmid-mediated SPM metallo-beta-lactamase conferring resistance to carbapenem. Originally isolated from Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Responsible for carbapenem-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa (CRPA) outbreaks in Brazil.

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus walK with mutation conferring daptomycin resistance

def.defstr: walK is the histidine kinase sensor of a two-component regulatory system controlling peptidoglycan metabolism through regulation of the expression of most of the peptidoglycan hydrolase genes. Mutations in the gene have been found that confer daptomycin resistance.
Mutations to the walK gene, part of a cell wall metabolism 2-component regulatory system, confers resistance to antibiotics, specifically daptomycin.
A class C beta-lactamase found in Acinetobacter baumannii that confers resistance to piperacillin and cefepime.

term.name: Enterococcus faecalis YybT with mutation conferring daptomycin resistance

def.defstr: YybT has phosphodiesterase activity towards cyclic dinucleotides using a c-di-GMP hydrolyzing phosphodiesterase domain. Mutations to the gene confer resistance to daptomycin.
Mutations to the YybT gene confers daptomycin resistance

term.name: Enterococcus faecalis gdpD with mutation conferring daptomycin resistance

def.defstr: gdpD is a glycerolphosphodiesterase whose mutations confer resistance to daptomycin.

Transmembrane protein which expels bicyclomycin from the cell, leading to bicyclomycin resistance. Identified in Pseudomonas aeruginosa strains responsible for outbreaks in Brazil, often appearing with blaSPM-1, another bicyclomycin resistance gene
Mutations to the gdpD glycerolphosphodiesterase confer resistance to daptomycin.

term.name: Staphylococcus aureus agrA with mutation conferring daptomycin resistance

def.defstr: agrA is an autoinducer in a peptide-quorum two-component regulatory system whose mutations confer daptomycin resistance.
Mutations to the regulatory gene agrA confer daptomycin resistance.

term.name: Enterococcus faecalis gshF with mutation conferring daptomycin resistance

def.defstr: gshF is a bifunctional glutamate-cysteine ligase/ glutathione synthetase that when mutated, confers daptomycin resistance.
Mutations to the glutathione synthetase gshF confers daptomycin resistance.

term.name: Escherichia coli acrR with mutation conferring multidrug antibiotic resistance

def.defstr: AcrR is a repressor of the AcrAB-TolC multidrug efflux complex. AcrR mutations result in high level antibiotic resistance. The mutations associated with this model are specific to E. coli.

carO is a transmembrane beta-barrel involved in the influx of carbapenem antibiotics in Acinetobacter baumannii. Disruption of the carO gene by distinct insertion elements results in a loss of carO expression causing resistance to carbapenem antibiotics. Homologs of carO have been identified in genera Acinetobacter, Moraxella and Psychrobacter.

term.name: Acinetobacter OprD conferring resistance to imipenem

def.defstr: An outer member protein (OMP) found in Acinetobacter baumannii involved in the uptake of imipenem and basic amino acids. This porin is homologous to Pseudomonas aeruginosa OprD, which performs an identical function.
Natural producers of kirromycin and kirromycin-like antibiotics (i.e., kirrothrycin) possess self-resistance, which is classified here
AdeC is the outer membrane factor of the AdeABC multidrug efflux complex. It can be replaced by other outer membrane channels, and is not essential for antibiotic resistance.

term.name: Enterococcus faecalis drmA with mutation conferring daptomycin resistance

def.defstr: drmA is an uncharacterized 6-pass membrane protein, with mutations to the protein causing modest resistance to daptomycin.
Mutations to drmA confer daptomycin resistance.

term.name: Enterococcus faecalis YvlB with mutation conferring daptomycin resistance

def.defstr: YvlB is a putative target of the liaFSR signalling pathway, whose mutations confer daptomycin resistance.
Mutations to the putative liaFSR target YvlB confer daptomycin resistance.

term.name: Acinetobacter baumannii gyrA conferring resistance to fluoroquinolones

def.defstr: Mutations in the A subunit of DNA gyrase reduce its affinity for fluoroquinolones, thereby conferring resistance.

term.name: Acinetobacter baumannii parC conferring resistance to fluoroquinolone

def.defstr: Mutations in Acinetobacter baumannii parC that result in resistance to fluoroquinolones.

mgrB is a small transmembrane protein produced in the PhoPQ signalling system. It acts as a negative regulator in this system. Inactivation or down-regulation of mgrB confers colistin resistance by absence as shown in Klebsiella pneumoniae

BAL30072 is a monocyclic beta-lactam antibiotic belonging to the sulfactams. BAL30072 was found to trigger the spheroplasting and lysis of Escherichia coli rather than the formation of extensive filaments.

Battacin is a cationic lipopeptide antibiotic produced from a Paenibacillus tianmuensis soil isolate. Battacin kills bacteria in vitro and has potent activity against Gram-negative bacteria, including multidrug-resistant and extremely drug-resistant clinical isolates. The bactericidal kinetics of battacin correlate with the depolarization of the cell membrane, suggesting that battacin kills bacteria by disrupting the cytoplasmic membrane.

Benzalkonium chloride is a type of cationic surfactant. It is an organic salt called a quaternary ammonium compound. It has three main categories of use: as a biocide, a cationic surfactant, and as a phase transfer agent.
A mixture of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim used to treat bacterial infections synergistically.

Rhodamine is a flurone dye that is often used as a tracer due to determine the rate and direction of flow and transport. It permeates the cell membrane of gram negative organisms E. coli and P. aeruginosa.
alanyl-tRNA synthetase conferring resistance to novobiocin in Escherichia coli
Temocillin is a beta-lactamase resistant carboxypenicillin. It is primarily used for the treatment of multiple drug resistant, Gram-negative bacteria, specifically Enterobacteriaceae.
